title: US GDP revised up but German consumer confidence slips - business live | Business | The Guardian
summary: european markets end downbeat week on a slightly better note .
us economy grew faster than originally thought over april-june .
german consumer confidence falls on economy worries .
banks face £ 2bn fines for rigging fx markets - sky .
eu seeks to clamp down on banks evading bonus cap .

documents.title: european markets end downbeat week on a slightly better note
text: the negatives certainly outweighed the positives this week , ranging from profit warnings from the likes of tesco to growing expectations of interest rate rises in the uk and us to worries about growth rates in china and the eurozone .
oh yes , and russian retaliation for the sanctions imposed in response to its actions in ukraine , and the repercussions of air strikes against isis .

but the week ended in marginally more upbeat fashion : the ftse 100 finished up 0.15 % or 9.68 points at 6649.39 ( but suffered its worst weekly performance for 15 months ) germany 's dax dipped 0.2 % to 9490.55 as allianz shares were hit by the departure of bill gross from its pimco business france 's cac closed up 0.91 % at 4394.75 italy 's ftse mib added 1.88 % to 20,795.37 spain 's ibex ended up 0.63 % at 10,851.4 on wall street the dow jones industrial average is currently up 78 points or 0.46 % .
and on that note , it 's time to close up for the evening .
thanks for all your comments , and we 'll be back on monday .
have a good weekend .
some good news for sweden - standard & poor 's has just confirmed its credit ratings at aaa with a stable outlook .
the agency said the ratings reflect a prosperous , competitive economy and successive governments ' commitment to prudent economic policies . ''
phew !
it did not expect a likely change in government to alter the key attributes of sweden 's economic policymaking . ''
over to greece where the country 's statistics agency has reported that salaries are continuing to drop .
the data comes on the heels of a parliamentary report revealing that far from being eased , poverty is also worsening in the debt-stricken country .
helena smith reports from athens : yet more evidence of greece 's austerity-driven depression in figures released by elstat , the country 's statistics office .
while fiscal adjustment continues apace , on the ground greeks are far from feeling the headway being made .

the agency reported today that in the second quarter of 2014 greece 's wage index dropped by 1.4 % compared to the same period last year - worsening an overall decline that now stands at 23.8 % since 2010 when europe 's debt crisis exploded in the greek capital .

raising the minimum wage has been a major demand of the main opposition radical left syriza party whose leader is heading the fight against what he describes as the perniciousness of merkelism '' in europe .

the drop follows publication of another report , this time by the greek parliament 's state budget office , revealing that three in every five greeks ( the equivalent of some 6.3m people ) were affected by poverty in 2013 either because of unemployment or material deprivation . ''

while some 2.5m people lived below the poverty threshold , another 3.8m were facing the threat of poverty , '' said the study entitled minimum income policies in the european union and greece : a comparative analysis . ''

unlike other eu member states , which implemented social programs to protect the poor , greece was acting slowly '' to shore up safety nets that until now had been provided traditionally by the family , the report maintained .
if there was help it was not only fragmented , '' but often the victim of administrative malfunctions , '' it said .
protests by public sector workers in thessaloniki this week .
photo : giannis papanikos/demotix/corbis papanikos/giannis papanikos/demotix/corbis

our full take on the us gdp figures from my colleague angela monaghan is now up : the us economy grew at its fastest rate for two and a half years in the second quarter after a broad-based in activity , boosting hopes of a sustained recovery .
the commerce department increased its estimate of gdp growth from an annual rate of 4.2 % to 4.6 % .

it was the best performance from the world 's largest economy since the fourth quarter of 2011 , and the upward revision was driven by stronger export growth and business spending than previously estimated .
it was a significant rebound from the 2.1 % annual drop in gdp in the first quarter of the year , when extreme weather disrupted the economy .
the latest revision was in line with wall street 's expectations .
full story here .
us consumer confidence in september hit its highest level for more than a year , according to a final reading on the thomson reuters/university of michigan survey .
the index of consumer sentiment rose from 82.5 at the end of august to 84.6 , the highest since july 2013 .
confidence was boosted by more favourable prospects for the us economy and higher expectations for personal income , according to the survey .

documents.title: us stocks recoup some losses
text: us stocks have risen this morning , recovering somewhat from their biggest drop since july .
dow jones +0.35 % standard and poors +0.22 % nasdaq +0.26 % the ftse100 is back in negative territory , while major european markets are having a mixed day .
german dax -0.45 % france 's cac +0.48 % that is all from me today .
nick fletcher will be posting further market updates later this afternoon .
thank you for reading and commenting so far .

meanwhile in slovenia benoît cœure , a member of the european central bank 's governing committee , has given a speech , where he argued that europe 's banks are in a stronger position to lend following health checks .
my main message today is simple : we need to focus on the quality of credit , not only the quantity .
unfortunately most economists do n't agree .
lending to private businesses needs to increase by 3 % a year but is unlikely to do so , according to a poll by reuters .
more essential reading on the bill gross/pimco story .
the wall street journal reported on wednesday that regulators at the us securities and exchange commission , were probing pimco over misleading information about the fund 's performance .

one possible focus of the sec inquiry , according to people familiar with the matter : whether pimco 's alleged maneuver meant investors were given inaccurate information about the fund 's performance .
it is a breach of securities law to provide investors with misleading information about values or performance , even if the wrong information was supplied unintentionally .
read the full story here
bill gross jumped before he was pushed .
this becomes evident from reading a statement from pimco 's chief executive officer , published by business insider .

while we are grateful for everything bill contributed to building our firm and delivering value to pimco 's clients , over the course of this year it became increasingly clear that the firm 's leadership and bill have fundamental differences about how to take pimco forward .
[ my emphasis ] .

as part of our responsibilities to our clients , employees and parent , pimco has been developing a succession plan for some time to ensure that the firm is well prepared to manage a seamless leadership transition in its portfolio management team
sid verma of euromoney flags up that andrew balls , brother of the shadow chancellor , could step into the top job at pimco .
andrew balls is a deputy chief investment officer , leading pimco 's european operations .
sid verma ( @ sidverma ) will ed balls ' brother get promoted now ?
bill gross may not be a ty super-rich fund manager .
he never trusted the exotic quantitative models that left many of his rivals exposed to toxic assets .
in an interview with the guardian he also said bankers , such as himself , ought to pay more taxes .
but he was tough when it came to managing his clients money , he insisted .
my clients do n't pay me to feel sorry , they pay me to bring them money .
i am tough but i have a soft side when i go home , i do n't watch fox [ the murdoch-owned right-wing news channel ] and i vote for obama .
he dealt a blow to the last labour government , when in the final months of gordon brown 's premiership , he warned that the uk 's economy was resting on a bed of nitroglycerine .
bill gross , co-founder and co-chief investment officer of pacific investment management company ( pimco ) , at the morningstar investment conference in chicago , illinois , in june .
jim young/reuters young/reuters the business world is pretty excited about the departure of bill gross , so-called bond king , from pimco , one of the largest money managers in the world .
he starts work at janus capital on monday , a fund with $ 177.7bn under management .
although janus is based in denver , gross will get his own office in newport beach , california .
janus shares have soared nearly 30 % in pre-market trading .
( hat tip fast ft ) this is despite questions about gross 's leadership style and the performance of his fund .

the us securities and exchange commission is also investigating whether a $ 3.6bn fund managed by gross exaggerated its numbers , while us papers have reported that officials are probing pimco itself .
here is what twitter users are saying about the us data .
one mumbai-based fund manager expects central bankers to raise interest rates .
sandip sabharwal ( @ sandipsabharwal ) us gdp grows faster than expected at 4.6 % in q2 .
rate hikes sooner than later .
the dow jones is expected to rise today , after yesterday 's sell off .
colin cieszynski ( @ ccieszynski cmc ) # dow drifts of its high of the morning but still holding 17,000 after us gdp revised up to 4.6 % as widely expected .
# trading # indices it 's not the only news market watchers ' attention today .
bill gross , the so-called bond king , is leaving pimco , the trillion-dollar fund he founded .
he starts at janus capital on monday .
yannis koutsomitis ( @ yannikouts ) within 5 minutes , us gdp lands at 4.6 % and bill gross leaves pimco .
more then a market can absorb in a whole day .
more details on the latest us data - revisions to earlier forecasts of q2 data .

bang on consensus , the figures shows that q2 gdp rose by 4.6 % , the fastest rate of expansion since q4 2011 ; us consumer spending rose 2.5 % ; exports rose 11.1 % and imports 11.3 % ; the dollar has gained against all major currencies .

documents.title: us economy grew faster than originally thought over april-june
text: breaking news : us q2 gdp has been revised upwards to 4.6 %
a dreamliner at boeing field in seattle , washington .
stephen brashear/getty images brashear/getty images a boeing 787 dreamliner flying from chicago to warsaw has been forced to make an emergency landing at glasgow airport .
poland 's lot airline that was operating the plane said it was forced to land following a fire protection alert from the baggage hold .
the aircraft has been assessed as safe by emergency services he added .
such events are closely watched , since the entire dreamliner fleet was grounded last year over suspected battery problems .

graffiti de german chancellor angela merkel is sprayed on a fence surrounding the construction site for the new headquarters of the european central bank ( ecb ) in frankfurt , kai pfaffenbach/reuters pfaffenbach/reuters the eurozone debt crisis has not gone away , it is just resting .
without a programme of debt forgiveness , europe 's economies can not return to growth .
this is the view of bob swarup , an investor and fellow of the institute of economic affairs , and we have just published his article on the guardian 's economics blog .
he argues that quantitative easing - monetary stimulus - can not be a solution to europe 's debt problem and puts forward an alternative plan .
europe needs its own brady bond plan .
aggregate the debt , reduce principals and coupons , and allow the markets to price it free of political rhetoric and monetary smokescreens .
use qe but as a salve to facilitate and ease the transition .

the ftse100 has been tipped into positive territory , thanks to a modest rally in banking stocks after a sky news report suggested that a probe into rigging foreign exchange rates would soon come to a close .
the ftse 350 banking index has risen 0.5 % , as investors take heart that a settlement is on the way , although the mood on barclays is more cautious .
rbs +0.2 % barclays -0.1 % hsbc +0.7 %
more on that ft story about the uk 's nominee for european commissioner , lord hill , being denied the power to oversee regulation on bankers bonuses .
the ft reported that the uk nominee had lost these responsibilities to ease his way through confirmation hearings with the european parliament , where there are vocal critics of hill 's appointment .

via reuters officials close to [ european commission president ] jean-claude juncker said the decision to move oversight of pay to the eu 's justice portfolio was made before hill was offered the post of eu commissioner for financial stability , financial services and capital markets union .
they said juncker decided that oversight of financial sector pay was better handled by the justice commission because that directorate already handles other corporate issues such as contract law .
some interesting comments from our readers on the german consumer confidence survey and general economic in europe ( click here if this text is a bit too small to read comfortably ) .
german consumer confidence : below the line business live : below the line

documents.title: german consumer confidence falls on economy worries
text: german consumer confidence worsened for the second successive month in september .
group german consumer confidence has fallen further amid concerns over conflicts in ukraine and economic weakness across europe , according to a closely-watched survey .
the consumer climate index published by the gfk group dropped to 8.3 from 8.6 in september .
a raft of measures that make up the index were down , including consumers ' willingness to buy and income expectations .
this was the second successive month that consumers ' optimism slipped , although the drop was less than in previous months .
the survey is based on 2,000 interviews .

documents.title: rouble hits all-time low
text: the russian rouble has hit a fresh all-time low against the dollar : it touched 38.97 earlier today , a nadir since the currency was relaunched in 1998 .
the rouble fell on friday , exceeding a historic low touched in mid september ( maxim zmeyev/reuters zmeyev/reuters

documents.title: banks face £ 2bn fines for rigging fx markets - sky
text: sky news is reporting that some of the uk 's largest banks could pay £ 2bn in fines for manipulation of global foreign exchange markets .

the city regulator has been in secret talks '' with the banks , which include barclays , hsbc and royal bank of scotland , to discuss the outline terms of a deal that could be announced as soon as november , according to sky .
foreign banks citi , jp morgan and ubs , have also been involved in the talks with the financial conduct authority .

here is a flavour : according to senior banking sources , the settlements , which would be confirmed simultaneously , could cost in the region of £ 2bn in total - which would be the uk regulator 's biggest-ever series of fines for the same offence .
the banks , which also include would pay different sums , depending on the gravity of their traders ' alleged efforts to artificially move foreign currency rates .

however , a person close to the talks said the fca had informed some of the banks ' lawyers that the smallest of the penalties imposed for foreign exchange-rigging were likely easily to outstrip the biggest of the fines it has so far handed out for manipulation of the interbank borrowing rate libor .

such an outcome would chime with a warning from martin wheatley , the fca chief executive , in february , when he told mps that allegations about collusion to rig prices in the $ 5.3tn ( £ 3.25tn ) spot market were every bit as bad as they have been with libor '' .
the financial conduct authority has declined to comment on the report .
air strikes in the middle east = rising oil prices ?
not necessarily .
brent crude fell has fallen below $ 97 a barrel this morning and is heading for its worst month since april 2013 .
some air and missile strikes have hit oilfields in eastern syria in an apparent attack by us-led forces against islamic state militants , reuters is reporting .
but prices are under pressure , with weak demand and plentiful supply .

cnn money has a helpful explainer on why prices are falling disruption to supplies is minimal ; the us is less dependent on foreign oil ; europe 's economies are slowing and the strong dollar is dampening demand .

brad mcmillan , chief investment officer at commonwealth financial group , is forecasting oil prices to fall further to $ 80- $ 85 the u.s. energy renaissance is just beginning the middle east is no longer as influential in setting oil prices
fund manager neil woodford also had a few interesting things to day about tesco .
my colleague sean farrell has been listening back to his interview on today and has out these lines .
i used to be a [ tesco ] shareholder some years ago and exited the position because i was concerned about some of the things that are playing out now .
clearly i did n't anticipate the sort of problem we have just heard about this week .
there are many structural and cyclical challenges .
when cyclical problems are overlaid with structural problems the solutions tend to be much , much more difficult and longer term .

so the industry , in the near term , faces a long road to exit this period of depressed margins and crushed profitability , and maybe asset bases [ and ] balance sheets need to be rebalanced in time before the industry can reemerge as an investable proposition from my point of view .
the immediate future is going to be tough for the sector but particularly for tesco .

documents.title: tesco finance director to up £ 1m payout
text: our latest story about troubled tesco , which has revealed it is to pay former finance director , laurie mcilwee , a £ 1m payoff next week , despite the £ 250m accounting scandal .
zoe wood , the guardian 's retail correspondent , reports that mcilwee will be paid the cash specified in his contract .
he quit the business in april and was told to stay away from the office - a period when it appears the finances of the uk 's largest retailer spun out of control . ''
read her full story here .

documents.title: moscow court seizes oil assets owned by imprisoned billionaire
text: a familiar tale from moscow .
a russian court has seized shares in the oil company bashneft , owned by sistema , the conglomerate controlled by wealthy businessman vladimir yevtushenkov , who is currently under house arrest .
the court alleges violations in the oil firm 's sale in 2009 - a case that raises parallels with the fate of mikhail khodorkovsky and his firm yukos .

here is the latest from reuters in moscow the court granted a request by the russian prosecutor general 's office , which said on friday it had uncovered significant violations '' of the law in the sale of energy assets in the ural mountains region of bashkortostan , including bashneft .

taking into consideration that the disposal of those assets was done in violation of procedures on the privatisation of state property , the prosecutor general 's office , with the aim of protecting state interests , has filed a lawsuit seeking interim measures involving the seizure of shares , '' it said .
to get the background on this tangled case , take a look at today 's big read in the ft .
in one especially choice quote , steven dashevsky , founder of dashevsky & partners , a russia-focused fund , tells the paper how the russian authorities ' tactics have changed .

before they were going after people who were politically inconvenient like khodorkovsky and [ exiled media magnate vladimir ] gusinsky , '' says now they 're going after people who are not part of the inner circle .
in these times neutrality is no longer enough .

documents.title: fund industry `` overcharges and underperforms ''
text: one of the country 's best performing fund managers , neil woodford , has said his industry overcharges its clients .
in an interview with bbc radio 4 's today programme , he said most fund managers are too short-termist and relied too heavily on index-tracker funds , rather than choosing stocks to invest in .
the industry has overcharged in many aspects .
it 's quite clear , in the banking industry and my own industry , that too often , the industry has been charging active fees for index performance or worse .
retail clients in particular are waking up to the high charges that we 've seen in the industry and i think , with some support from the regulator , we 're going to see those charges come down .
in another interesting line , he also predicted that pfizer would renew its offer to takeover the uk 's second largest pharmaceutical firm astrazeneca .
kamal ahmed ( @ bbckamal ) neil woodford tells @ twitterid that he thinks pfizer will come back for a further bid for astra zeneca @ twitterid4today

documents.title: eu seeks to clamp down on banks evading bonus cap
text: the financial times ' splash also caught my eye .
the paper reports that european regulators are planing to clamp down on banks that attempt to sidestep the bankers ' bonus cap by paying their top staff allowances .
stuart gulliver , chief executive of hsbc gets an allowance worth £ 32,000 a week - on top of his £ 1.2m salary , to get around the eu 's cap on bonuses .
many other big banks have followed suit with similar deals for their staff .
now the eu is trying to close this loophole .

the ft reports if the draft is adopted and enforced by uk authorities , banks including hsbc , barclays and goldman sachs will be forced to rethink their allowance regimes in another twist ( that appears online ) the paper reports that lord hill , the uk 's next european commissioner , will not get responsibilities for enforcement of the bankers ' bonus cap .

lord hill , a former lobbyist , is taking responsibility for financial services regulation , but jean-claude juncker , the european commission , decided that transferring responsibilities for bankers ' pay to another part of the commission , would help disarm hill 's critics in the european parliament .

from today 's daily telegraph daily papers ( @ ukpapers ) buy-to-let borrowers face new costs and limits - @ twitterid watt # frontpages buy-to-let property owners could face new restrictions under eu rules , according to the paper 's splash .

the financial conduct authority , the uk 's financial services watchdog , is tightening up affordability criteria for loans in response to the eu 's mortgage credit directive adopted earlier this year .

accidental landlords '' - people who can not live in a property for work reasons or those who have inherited property - could be caught out by the changes , according to legal experts , although the treasury is not clear how many people will be affected .
banknote analogies are hard to resist when it comes to de la rue 's profit warning .
bhaven patel ( @ bhaven patel ) de la rue shares down 26 % after profit warning - that 's a very big pile of freshly printed £ 50 notes that has been set on fire !
# dlar

documents.title: banknote printer shares plummet after profits warning
text: apparently it does n't always pay to be in the business of printing money .
de la rue , which prints pounds sterling for the bank of england , is suffering a rout on the markets this morning after issuing a dramatic profits warning .
shares in de la rue , a ftse 250 company , have plunged by more than 26 % after the firm announced that profits would be £ 20m lower than previously expected .
it has also slashed its dividend to 8.3p a share , down from 14.14p .
de la rue is blaming tougher competition in the banknote printing business .
the challenging market conditions reported at the agm have deteriorated further with lower prices and reduced margins in both banknote print and paper .
and things are n't expected to get better anytime soon .
based on recent orders and current trends within both the currency and solutions divisions the board expects the current difficult market conditions to continue in the 2015/16 financial year .
sounds like a tall order for de la rue 's new chief executive martin sutherland , who is due to join the company on 13 october .
good morning , and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy , the financial markets , the eurozone and the business world .
european markets are set for a mixed day of trading , following a sharp sell off in asia this morning .
the msci index of asia pacific shares is down 1 % to its lowest level since june .
the region 's largest stock market , the nikkei has also fallen 1 % , after data showed that japanese inflation eased in august raising concerns about the economy 's lacklustre performance .
analysts think the bank of japan could be forced into further financial stimulus .
meanwhile , us stocks endured their biggest one-day fall since july , led by apple .
the tech company was forced to withdraw a software update from its operating system - an event analysts deem more damaging than the storm in a teacup over bending phones .
european markets are expected to dip again , over fears that russia is preparing to seize western assets .

jasper lawler at cmc markets writes : if there 's confirmation regarding a proposed piece of legislation in russia to allow foreign asset-seizure ; the dax with germany 's strong russian trading ties and the ftse 100 with the uk 's large energy-investment in russia could see another bout of selling .
apart from that there is not a lot in the diary .
perhaps the biggest event is the final revision of us gdp data for august that is expected to show the us economy grew faster than previously thought .
more to follow
